denali: Home to North America's tallest peak (20,310 ft), offering six million acres of wild land where grizzly bears, caribou, and wolves roam freely.
gates-arctic: America's northernmost national park with no roads or trails, offering a pristine wilderness experience above the Arctic Circle.
glacier-bay: A stunning tidewater glacier wonderland where massive ice walls calve into the sea, surrounded by humpback whales and sea lions.
katmai: Famous for its brown bears fishing for salmon at Brooks Falls, plus the otherworldly Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes volcanic landscape.
kenai-fjords: Where the Harding Icefield feeds over 40 glaciers that flow down to the sea, creating a dramatic coastline teeming with marine life.
kobuk-valley: Home to the Great Kobuk Sand Dunes and the annual migration of half a million caribou through pristine Arctic wilderness.
lake-clark: A diverse wilderness combining smoking volcanoes, turquoise lakes, salmon-filled rivers, and some of Alaska's best bear viewing.
wrangell-st-elias: The largest US national park, featuring nine of the sixteen highest peaks in the country and glaciers larger than Rhode Island.
arches: Contains over 2,000 natural sandstone arches including the iconic Delicate Arch, Utah's most famous natural landmark.
bryce-canyon: Not actually a canyon but a series of natural amphitheaters filled with thousands of red, orange, and white hoodoo rock formations.
canyonlands: A dramatic landscape carved by the Colorado and Green Rivers into countless canyons, mesas, and buttes spanning 337,598 acres.
capitol-reef: A hidden gem featuring the 100-mile Waterpocket Fold, ancient petroglyphs, and historic orchards you can freely pick from.
zion: Towering red cliffs, emerald pools, and the famous Narrows hike through a slot canyon carved by the Virgin River.
crater-lake: The deepest lake in the USA (1,943 ft), formed in a collapsed volcano, with impossibly blue water and Wizard Island rising from its center.
death-valley: The hottest, driest, and lowest place in North America, featuring surreal salt flats, sand dunes, and the mysterious sailing stones.
grand-teton: Dramatic granite peaks rising abruptly 7,000 feet above the valley floor, with pristine alpine lakes and world-class wildlife viewing.
great-basin: Features the ancient bristlecone pines (some over 5,000 years old) and Nevada's only glacier beneath 13,063 ft Wheeler Peak.
joshua-tree: Where the Mojave and Colorado deserts meet, filled with surreal twisted Joshua trees and giant boulder formations perfect for climbing.
kings-canyon: One of North America's deepest canyons, featuring giant sequoia groves and the towering granite walls of Kings River canyon.
lassen-volcanic: The world's largest plug dome volcano and all four types of volcanoes found in one park, with bubbling mud pots and steaming fumaroles.
mount-rainier: An active stratovolcano wrapped in glaciers and wildflower meadows, dominating Seattle's skyline at 14,411 feet.
north-cascades: Over 300 glaciers and countless jagged peaks make this the American Alps, with some of the most rugged wilderness in the lower 48.
olympic: Three distinct ecosystems in one park: glacier-capped mountains, temperate rainforest with 12 feet of annual rain, and wild Pacific coastline.
pinnacles: Ancient volcanic spires and caves formed 23 million years ago, now home to reintroduced California condors and exceptional rock climbing.
redwood: Home to the tallest trees on Earth, including Hyperion at 380 feet, and herds of Roosevelt elk wandering through misty ancient forests.
sequoia: Protects the General Sherman Tree, the world's largest tree by volume, and the rugged Sierra Nevada high country.
yellowstone: The world's first national park, featuring half of Earth's geothermal features, Old Faithful, and the largest concentration of mammals in the lower 48.
yosemite: Famous for its giant ancient sequoias and Tunnel View, the iconic vista of towering Bridalveil Fall and the granite cliffs of El Capitan and Half Dome.
glacier: The Crown of the Continent with over 700 miles of trails, Going-to-the-Sun Road, and rapidly retreating glaciers.
channel-islands: Five remote islands off California's coast, called 'North America's Galapagos' for their unique wildlife and pristine waters.
big-bend: A remote Texas wilderness where the Rio Grande carves spectacular canyons and the Chisos Mountains rise from the Chihuahuan Desert.
carlsbad-caverns: Over 100 caves including the famous Big Room, plus nightly bat flights of hundreds of thousands of Brazilian free-tailed bats.
grand-canyon: A mile-deep gorge carved by the Colorado River over 6 million years, revealing 2 billion years of geological history.
guadalupe-mountains: Texas's highest point and the world's most extensive Permian fossil reef, with fall colors in McKittrick Canyon.
mesa-verde: Preserves over 5,000 archaeological sites including 600 cliff dwellings built by Ancestral Puebloans over 700 years ago.
petrified-forest: A painted desert landscape scattered with colorful fossilized logs from 225-million-year-old forests.
saguaro: Protects the nation's largest cacti, the iconic saguaro, which can live 200 years and grow 50 feet tall in the Sonoran Desert.
white-sands: The world's largest gypsum dune field, creating an otherworldly white landscape that can be seen from space.
black-canyon: The Gunnison River carved this dramatically narrow gorge with some walls dropping 2,722 feet, among the steepest in North America.
rocky-mountain: Colorado's high country with 77 peaks over 12,000 feet, alpine tundra, abundant wildlife, and the famous Trail Ridge Road.
great-sand-dunes: North America's tallest dunes (750 feet) nestled against the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, with a seasonal beach and creek for sand sledding.
badlands: Dramatic striped rock formations and one of the world's richest fossil beds, with bison, bighorn sheep, and prairie dogs.
cuyahoga-valley: Ohio's only national park, featuring 33,000 acres of forests, hills, and waterfalls along the historic Ohio & Erie Canal.
gateway-arch: St. Louis's iconic 630-foot stainless steel arch commemorating America's westward expansion, with tram rides to the top.
indiana-dunes: 15 miles of Lake Michigan shoreline with diverse ecosystems, from beaches and dunes to wetlands and prairies.
isle-royale: A remote island wilderness in Lake Superior, famous for the longest-running predator-prey study of wolves and moose.
theodore-roosevelt: The rugged North Dakota badlands that inspired our conservation president, with wild horses, bison, and elk.
voyageurs: A water-based park with over 200,000 acres of interconnected waterways, dark sky preserves, and excellent fishing.
wind-cave: One of the world's longest caves with unique boxwork formations, plus the first national park created to protect a cave.
acadia: The first national park east of the Mississippi, where mountains meet the Atlantic along Maine's rugged coast.
biscayne: 95% underwater, protecting the northernmost Florida Keys, pristine coral reefs, and the third-largest reef system in the world.
congaree: The largest intact expanse of old-growth bottomland hardwood forest in the US, with champion trees and synchronized firefly displays.
dry-tortugas: A remote island fortress (Fort Jefferson) surrounded by crystal-clear waters, pristine beaches, and world-class snorkeling.
everglades: The largest subtropical wilderness in the US, where the 'River of Grass' supports panthers, manatees, and over 350 bird species.
great-smoky-mountains: America's most visited national park, with ancient mountains cloaked in mist, synchronous fireflies, and astounding biodiversity.
hot-springs: The oldest federal reserve (1832), offering natural thermal waters and beautiful bathhouses in downtown Hot Springs.
mammoth-cave: The world's longest known cave system with over 400 miles explored, featuring dramatic underground rivers and formations.
new-river-gorge: America's newest national park, featuring world-class whitewater rafting and the famous New River Gorge Bridge.
shenandoah: Virginia's Blue Ridge Mountains along 105 miles of Skyline Drive, with over 500 miles of trails including part of the Appalachian Trail.
virgin-islands: Pristine Caribbean beaches, turquoise waters, coral reefs, and historic Danish sugar plantation ruins on St. John.
haleakala: A massive shield volcano rising 10,023 feet above sea level, famous for sunrise viewing and rare silversword plants.
hawaii-volcanoes: Home to Kilauea, one of the world's most active volcanoes, with flowing lava, steam vents, and diverse rainforest ecosystems.
american-samoa: The only US national park south of the equator, protecting tropical rainforests, coral reefs, and 3,000-year-old Samoan culture.
tokyo: A dazzling mix of neon-lit skyscrapers, historic temples, and the world's best food scene from Michelin stars to tiny ramen shops.
delhi: A chaotic tapestry of ancient Mughal architecture, vibrant bazaars, and diverse cuisines spanning India's rich history.
shanghai: China's futuristic metropolis where the iconic Bund waterfront meets Pudong's space-age skyline and traditional lane houses.
beijing: Home to the Forbidden City, Great Wall, and 3,000 years of imperial history blended with modern Olympic architecture.
mumbai: India's city of dreams, where Bollywood glamour meets colonial architecture, street food culture, and the iconic Gateway of India.
osaka: Japan's kitchen and comedy capital, famous for takoyaki, okonomiyaki, and a more laid-back vibe than Tokyo.
bangkok: The City of Angels offers ornate temples, floating markets, legendary street food, and a nightlife scene that never stops.
seoul: K-pop, K-beauty, and kimchi meet ancient palaces in this 24-hour city with the world's fastest internet and best fried chicken.
singapore: A garden city of the future, blending Chinese, Malay, and Indian cultures with world-class hawker food and Marina Bay's stunning skyline.
hong-kong: A vertical city of sky-high towers and dim sum parlors, where East meets West on Victoria Harbour's iconic waterfront.
london: Historic royalty meets cutting-edge culture, from the Tower of London to Tate Modern, with the world's best theatre scene.
paris: The City of Light, known for the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre, charming cafe culture, and the birthplace of haute cuisine.
moscow: Red Square, the Kremlin, and onion-domed cathedrals showcase Russia's imperial grandeur and Soviet legacy.
istanbul: Where Europe meets Asia across the Bosphorus, with Byzantine churches, Ottoman mosques, and the Grand Bazaar's 4,000 shops.
berlin: A city reborn after reunification, mixing world-class museums, groundbreaking nightlife, and powerful history.
madrid: Spain's elegant capital, famous for Prado masterpieces, late-night tapas crawls, and Europe's most vibrant nightlife.
rome: The Eternal City of Colosseum gladiators, Vatican treasures, and perfected la dolce vita around every cobblestone corner.
barcelona: Gaudi's surreal architecture, Mediterranean beaches, world-class football, and endless nights in the Gothic Quarter.
amsterdam: Canals, bicycles, and gabled houses create a charming backdrop for Van Gogh, Rembrandt, and legendary coffee shops.
new-york: The city that never sleeps, featuring Times Square, Central Park, world-class museums, and unmatched cultural diversity.
los-angeles: Hollywood dreams, Santa Monica beaches, and a sprawling metropolis where every neighborhood has its own personality.
chicago: World-class architecture, deep-dish pizza, blues and jazz heritage, and a spectacular lakefront skyline.
san-francisco: The Golden Gate, cable cars, Alcatraz, and a tech-forward city famous for its Victorian houses and fog.
miami: Art Deco dreams, Cuban coffee, and endless beaches where Latin American culture meets American glamour.
toronto: Canada's most diverse city, with the CN Tower overlooking world-class food, multicultural neighborhoods, and island escapes.
vancouver: Mountains meet the Pacific in this outdoor paradise, with Stanley Park, diverse cuisine, and stunning natural beauty.
sydney: The Opera House and Harbour Bridge frame this sun-drenched city of beaches, bushwalks, and unbeatable quality of life.
melbourne: Australia's cultural capital, famous for laneway cafes, street art, sport, and the world's most liveable city status.
dubai: A futuristic desert oasis of record-breaking skyscrapers, luxury shopping, and artificial islands.
cairo: The gateway to ancient Egypt, where the Pyramids of Giza and Egyptian Museum reveal 5,000 years of civilization.
rio-de-janeiro: Christ the Redeemer watches over beaches, samba, and carnival in one of the world's most beautiful cities.
buenos-aires: The Paris of South America, passionate about tango, steak, wine, and late-night conversations.
mexico-city: Ancient Aztec ruins, colonial palaces, world-class museums, and arguably the best food scene in the Americas.
louvre: The world's largest art museum, home to the Mona Lisa and 35,000 works spanning 9,000 years of human history.
met: New York's encyclopedic treasure house with over 2 million works from Egyptian temples to modern masterpieces.
british-museum: Over 8 million objects including the Rosetta Stone, Parthenon sculptures, and Egyptian mummies, all free to visit.
vatican-museums: 2,000 years of papal collecting culminates in the breathtaking Sistine Chapel ceiling.
rijksmuseum: The Netherlands' national museum, showcasing Rembrandt's Night Watch and Vermeer's Milkmaid.
uffizi: The Medici art collection in Florence, featuring Botticelli's Birth of Venus and Renaissance masterpieces.
prado: Spain's royal art collection, with the world's finest works by Velazquez, Goya, and El Greco.
hermitage: One of the world's largest museums, housed in the Winter Palace with 3 million items including da Vinci and Rembrandt.
moma: The most influential modern art museum, home to Van Gogh's Starry Night and Picasso's Les Demoiselles d'Avignon.
tate-modern: London's modern art powerhouse in a converted power station, showcasing the best of contemporary art.
guggenheim-bilbao: Frank Gehry's titanium masterpiece transformed Bilbao into a must-visit destination for architecture and art lovers.
acropolis-museum: A stunning showcase of ancient Greek artifacts from the Acropolis, with breathtaking views of the Parthenon.
van-gogh: The world's largest collection of Van Gogh works, including Sunflowers and The Bedroom.
magic-kingdom: Where dreams come true at Disney's flagship park, featuring Cinderella Castle and classic attractions since 1971.
disneyland: Walt's original dream, the Happiest Place on Earth, where Sleeping Beauty Castle started the Disney magic in 1955.
universal-orlando: Bringing movies to life with Wizarding World of Harry Potter, thrilling rides, and immersive experiences.
europa-park: Germany's largest theme park, with 18 themed countries, world-class coasters, and European charm.
tokyo-disneysea: The world's most elaborate Disney park, featuring stunning themed ports and attractions unique to Japan.
cedar-point: The Roller Coaster Capital of the World, with 17 coasters including millennium-force record-breakers.
fenway-park: Baseball's most beloved ballpark, home of the Red Sox since 1912, featuring the iconic Green Monster.
wrigley-field: The Friendly Confines of Chicago Cubs baseball, with ivy-covered walls and historic neighborhood charm.
yankee-stadium: The House That Ruth Built (rebuilt), where 27 World Series championships created baseball's greatest dynasty.
camp-nou: Europe's largest football stadium, the legendary home of FC Barcelona and some of the sport's greatest moments.
old-trafford: The Theatre of Dreams, Manchester United's iconic home for over a century of football history.
